titleStmt.title: Proverbs: collection 21 -- an English prose translation

publicationStmt.distributor: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature

address.addrLine: The Oriental Institute, University of Oxford, Pusey Lane, Oxford OX1 2LE, UK, email etcsl@orinst.ox.ac.uk, http://etcsl.orinst.ox.ac.uk

seriesStmt.p: The Electronic Text Corpus of Sumerian Literature aims to make accessible over 400 literary works composed in the Sumerian language in ancient Mesopotamia during the late third and early second millennia BC. The works are in Sumerian composite transliteration and English prose translation with bibliographical information on each composition.

sourceDesc.p: Sources are listed in the header of the composite text

lg.p: = Alster 1997 21 Sec. B 3 The king &X;&X; not having questioned &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. B 4; cf. 6.1.09.a12, 6.1.19.b1, 6.1.24.2, 6.2.5: YBC 4677 ll. 1-2 When a fattened pig is about to be slaughtered &X;&X;, one says Let me replace what I am about to eat.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. B 5; cf. 6.1.09.a13, 6.1.19.b2, 6.1.24.2, 6.2.5: YBC 4677 ll. 3-4 As the piglet snuffles around, it says &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 1; cf. 6.1.19.c7, 6.1.23.18, 6.1.24.8 A man's daughter-in-law is his policeman.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 2; cf. 6.1.19.c8 A fiancée &X;&X; I &X;&X; to the house. May I &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 Sec. A 3; cf. 6.1.01.191 May &X;&X; eat the ham of a pig! &X;&X; pig &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 4; cf. 6.1.24.10 I would make the beer sweet but my neighbour would not appreciate it.

p.note: = Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 5; cf. 6.1.24.11; edited separately as 5.6.9 The fowler and his wife

lg.p: = Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 6 The slave girl roams around when it grows dark as if it were midnight.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 7; cf. 6.1.19.d10 The litter was not apparent to the slave girl. To her mistress &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 8; cf. 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. B l. 5 Dusk means joy for a daughter-in-law.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 9; cf. 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. B l. 7 It was of value to her. She is the slave girl of a &X;&X;.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 10; cf. 6.2.3: UET 6/2 325 ll. 1-2, 6.2.5: IM 62823 Seg. B ll. 8-9 The slave girls did not take out the bala&g; drum. Inana &X;&X; in the village (?).
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 11; cf. 6.1.03.37 The slave girl from the palace offers advice (?) continually.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 12; cf. 6.1.03.37 The slave from the palace eats the ex-voto offering perhaps an idiom.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 13 If I &X;&X;, my vagina brings me slavery. Will anyone take my vagina then?
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 14; cf. 6.1.19.d3 The &X;&X; bird flees, running away from its own behind.
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 15; cf. 6.1.09.b2 You should cut it, she said &X;&X; to me. It is a slave girl's princess!

p.note: = Alster 1997 21 Sec. A 16; cf. 6.1.09.b4, 6.1.09.b5-8; edited separately as 5.6.8 The lazy slave girl

lg.p: = Alster 1997 21 Sec. D 2 A lamentation singer &X;&X; not &X;&X; a gur weight of barley &X;&X; barge &X;&X;.

= Alster 1997 21 Sec. D 3 A lamentation priest went into a man's field to steal the barley. The owner of the field caught him. My beautiful head got confused! It is totally bewildered. Just let me straighten it out, let me &X;&X; my senses! Let me go free!
= Alster 1997 21 Sec. D 4 A field, whose owner, a friend of a lamentation priest, &X;&X;

div1.note: = Alster 1997 p. 260 UM 29-13-264a; unplaced; belongs somewhere after 21.c5
= Alster 1997 p. 260 N 7918; unplaced; may not belong in collection 21
